blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Women Executives
Barometer 2024

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
18 Report by Virginia Sondergeld, Katharina Wrohlich, and Anja Kirsch

Share of women on the executive boards of
large companies has increased, but generally is
at most one woman

The DIW Berlin Women Executives Barometer is the largest survey on
women in leadership positions of large companies in Germany

Share of women at top 200 companies around 18 percent in late

fall 2023

Many companies have appointed no more than one woman to their
executive board for the first time
blocks.summarized_text: The share of women on the executive boards of large companies in Germany has increased, but generally, there is at most one woman. The DIW Berlin Women Executives Barometer revealed that around 18 percent of top 200 companies had appointed no more than one woman to their executive board in late fall 2023.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Share of women on the executive boards of large
companies has increased, but generally is at most
one woman

Bw VUiedninin Candarnoald Watharinn Wereaklicekh and Anim Mivrcrk

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
The largest analysis of its kind, the DIW Berlin Women Executives Barometer contains information
on shares of women on the executive and supervisory boards of over 500 companies

Number of women on executive boards of largest companies in Germany increased considerably;
the top 200 companies had a share of around 18 percent in late fall 2023

Many companies have appointed no more than one woman to their executive board for the first
time; 44 percent of the top 200 group still has no women on the executive board

More commitment needed from companies, both internally and externally, to achieve equal
participation of men and women in management positions
blocks.summarized_text: The DIW Berlin Women Executives Barometer found that while there has been an increase in the number of women on executive boards in Germany, there is still a lack of equal representation. With only 18 percent of the top 200 companies having women on their executive boards, more effort is needed both internally and externally to achieve gender equality in management positions.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text: WOMEN EXECUTIVES BAROMETER: SHARE OF WOMEN

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
Share of women on the executive boards
of large companies has increased, but
generally is at most one woman
blocks.summarized_text: The share of women on executive boards of large companies has increased, but typically there is only one woman represented. Despite progress, there is still a lack of gender diversity at the highest levels of corporate leadership.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text: ABSTRACT

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
The number of women serving on the executive boards of
large companies in Germany once again increased in 2023:
Around 18 percent (153 of 875) of executive board members
at the 200 largest companies were women as of late fall 2023,
two percentage points higher than in 2022. Thus, growth has
slightly picked up again. In some of the groups of companies
analyzed, the figure was even higher. Around 23 percent

of executive board members at the DAX 40 companies,

for example, are women. The largest banks and insurance
companies, which in the past years have lagged considerably
behind other private sector companies and companies with
government-owned shares, managed to catch up a bit. In
many places, this growth is due to the fact that companies
have appointed a woman to their executive board for the first
time. Beyond that, there is currently not much progress. In
addition, the number of women holding the position of CEO
has decreased in many groups of companies. More commit-
ment is needed from companies, both internally (e.g., from
the supervisory board) and externally (e.g., from investors) to

achieve gender parity in senior leadership positions.
blocks.summarized_text: The number of women on executive boards of large companies in Germany increased in 2023, with around 18% of board members being women. However, there is still a lack of progress in increasing the number of women CEOs, and more commitment is needed from companies and investors to achieve gender parity in senior leadership positions.

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
Since 2006, DIW Berlin’s Women Executives Barometer has
been documenting the share of women! on management
boards and among managing directors (hereafter referred
to as “executive boards”) as well as on supervisory, admin-
istrative, and advisory boards as well as boards of trustees
(hereafter “supervisory boards”) of the largest companies
in Germany.’ It is also documented to what extent women
hold executive board chair and executive board spokesper-
son positions (hereafter “CEO”) as well as supervisory board
chair positions. These shares of women are reported here
for the 200 largest companies in Germany (measured by
revenue),* all DAX companies,‘ all companies with govern-
ment-owned shares,’ the 100 largest banks*® (measured by
balance sheet total), and the 60 largest insurance companies’
(measured by revenue from contributions}. Furthermore,
the shares of women on executive boards and supervisory
boards are reported separately for the companies subject to
the gender quota on supervisory boards and for the compa-
nies subject to the 2021 inclusion requirement® for execu-

1.) This Weekly Report uses a binary understanding of gender. The gender of the persons
blocks.summarized_text: The report focuses on the representation of women in executive and supervisory board positions of major companies in Germany, using a binary understanding of gender. It documents the share of women in leadership roles such as managing directors and executive board chair positions, providing insights into gender diversity in corporate governance.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Women on executive and supervisory boards of Germany's 200 largest companies’ (excluding the
financial sector)

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
tive boards. Altogether, the DIW Berlin Women Executives
Barometer includes information on over 500 companies in
Germany. The figures published here were researched from
November 15 to November 27, 2023.° The data are drawn
from online company profiles, 2022 annual reports, finan-
cial statements, and the German Federal Government’s 2022
Beteiligungsbericht. It also includes information from German
Federal Gazette publications as well as specifc data requests
made to the companies by DIW Berlin.
blocks.summarized_text: The DIW Berlin Women Executives Barometer provides information on over 500 companies in Germany, researched in November 2023. Data sources include online profiles, annual reports, financial statements, government reports, and specific company requests.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Top 200 companies

Share of women on executive boards continues to
rise, but number of women CEOs is declining

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
In the fourth quarter of 2023, the share of women on the
executive boards of the 200 largest companies (excluding the
financial sector) was nearly 18 percent (Table 1 and Figure 1),
an increase of almost two percentage points compared to
blocks.summarized_text: In the fourth quarter of 2023, women made up nearly 18 percent of executive boards in the top 200 largest companies, excluding the financial sector. This marked an increase of almost two percentage points from the previous period.

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
2022. Thus, following rather restrained growth in 2022, the
share of women has begun to increase again. Since 2018,
the share of women on the executive boards of the 200 larg-
est companies has almost doubled.

The development among the top 100 companies was similar:
There, the share of women on executive boards also increased
by nearly two percentage points and, as of late fall 2023, was
over 19 percent. This share has also almost doubled since 2018.

The increase in the share of women on executive boards, how-
ever, contrasts with a decline in the share of women CEOs:
In both the top 200 and the top 100 companies, the number
of women CEOs fell by one person in each case. Only nine
(five percent) of the 200 largest companies had a woman CEO
as of fall 2023, while only four (a little over four percent) of
the 100 largest had a woman CEO.”
blocks.summarized_text: The share of women on executive boards of top companies has nearly doubled since 2018, with an increase in late fall 2023. However, the number of women CEOs has declined, with only a small percentage holding CEO positions in the largest companies.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Figure 1

Shares of women and men in selected groups of companies
In percent

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Slight growth in the share of women on
supervisory boards

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
The share of women on supervisory boards remains signifi-
cantly higher than the share of women on executive boards;
recently the shares at both the 200 and 100 largest compa-
nies increased by nearly one percentage point each to around
32 percent. On average, women have made up almost one
third of supervisory board members for several years now.
The number of women leading a supervisory board among
the 200 largest companies grew from 11 in 2022 to 13, a good
eight percent, in late fall 2023." In the fourth quarter of 2023,
the 100 largest companies had seven women (eight percent)
supervisory board chairs.
blocks.summarized_text: The share of women on supervisory boards is higher than on executive boards, with around 32% at the 200 and 100 largest companies. The number of women leading supervisory boards at these companies increased from 11 to 13 in late fall 2023.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Publicly listed companies

DAX 40 companies have the largest share of
women on executive boards, but MDAX and
TecDAX companies are catching up

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
In late fall 2023, the average share of women on the executive
boards of the 160 publicly listed companies analyzed here
(DAX 40, MDAX, SDAX, and TecDAX) was a good 18 per-
cent, thus nearly three percentage points higher than in
2022. This share is very similar to the shares of women on
the executive boards of the 200 and 100 largest companies.

However, this average conceals major differences between
the individual DAX groups. The largest publicly listed compa-
nies, the DAX 40, have had a larger share of women on their
executive boards than the SDAX, MDAX, and TecDAX com-
panies for more than ten years (Table 2 and Table 3). There
was a particularly strong increase in the share of women at
the executive level in the DAX 40 group between 2020 and
2022 from almost 15 percent to nearly 22 percent. Recently,
this momentum has slowed a bit; in the fourth quarter of
2023, the share of women on the executive boards of the
DAX 40 companies was 23 percent, only a good one percent-
age point higher than in 2022. This means that in late fall
2023, 59 ofa total of 256 executive board members across the
40 largest publicly listed companies were women.
blocks.summarized_text: In late fall 2023, the average share of women on the executive boards of publicly listed companies analyzed was 18%, almost 3% higher than in 2022. The DAX 40 companies have had a larger share of women on their executive boards for over a decade, with a recent increase bringing the share to 23% in late 2023.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Table 2

Women on executive and supervisory boards of DAX 30/DAX 40 and MDAX companies'

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
The MDAX companies, in contrast, experienced consider-
ably more growth: Here, the share of women on executive
boards increased by nearly six percentage points and was
nearly 18 percent most recently. The TecDAX companies
have developed similarly (Table 3): The share of women on
executive boards experienced a comparatively strong increase
of nearly five percentage points to around 21 percent. The
share of women on the executive boards of SDAX companies
grew much less: Ata good 14 percent, the SDAX companies
have the lowest share of women executive board members
ofall DAX groups. Moreover, the increase was not especially
large, at only around two percentage points.

In contast to the growth of women on executive boards, the
growth of women CEOs was either negative or stagnated, as
is the case at the 200 and 100 largest companies. While two
DAX 40 companies had women CEOs in 2022, as of late fall
2023, there was only one: Belén Garijo, the CEO of Merck.
One TecDAX company had a woman CEO in 2022, butas of
late fall 2023, that is no longer the case. There was no change
in the MDAX and SDAX companies, where there were two
blocks.summarized_text: The MDAX and TecDAX companies saw noticeable growth in the representation of women on executive boards, with increases of nearly six and five percentage points respectively. However, the SDAX companies had the lowest share of women on executive boards at around 14 percent, with only a small increase of about two percentage points.

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
and five women CEOs, respectively, as of the fourth quarter
of 2023, as was the case in 2022. Comparing the DAX groups,
the SDAX companies were ahead at just over seven percent
women CEOs, which contrasts with their comparatively low
share of women among executive board members overall.”
blocks.summarized_text: In the fourth quarter of 2023, the number of women CEOs in DAX and SDAX companies remained consistent with the previous year. SDAX companies had a higher percentage of women CEOs at just over seven percent, despite having a lower representation of women among executive board members overall.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Slight increase in the share of women on
supervisory boards of all DAX groups

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
In late fall 2023, the average share of women on supervisory
boards at all 160 DAX companies was nearly 36 percent,
around two percentage points higher than in 2022.

The DAX 40 and TecDAX companies both had the greatest
share of women on supervisory boards at a good 38 percent
each. They are followed by the MDAX companies (36 per-
cent} and SDAX companies (a little over 33 percent). MDAX
blocks.summarized_text: In late fall 2023, the average share of women on supervisory boards at all 160 DAX companies was nearly 36 percent, a two percentage point increase from 2022. The DAX 40 and TecDAX companies had the highest representation of women at 38 percent each, followed by MDAX companies at 36 percent and SDAX companies at a little over 33 percent.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Table 3

Women on executive and supervisory boards of SDAX and TecDAX companies’

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
companies recently experienced the most growth, with the
share of women on supervisory boards increasing by over
two percentage points, while growth in the other DAX groups
was around one percentage point each. The share of women
supervisory board chairs did not increase, with the exception
of the TecDAX companies. In contrast, the number of women
supervisory board chairs at DAX 40 companies was halved,
from four to two. Thus, in the fourth quarter of 2023, only a
good five percent of DAX 40 companies had a woman head-
ing the supervisory board. The number of women supervi-
sory board chairs at MDAX companies remained the same
(two women — four percent). Meanwhile, there was a decline
among the SDAX companies (from three to two women),
and with that, the share of women supervisory board chairs
was only barely three percent as of late fall 2023. Compared
to 2022, there was an additional woman supervisory board
chair in the TecDAX companies. Here, two women (nearly
seven percent) were supervisory board chairs in the fourth
quarter of 2023.”
blocks.summarized_text: In the fourth quarter of 2023, the share of women on supervisory boards increased significantly in DAX companies, particularly in TecDAX. However, the number of women heading supervisory boards decreased in DAX 40 companies. Overall, there was only a small increase in the number of women supervisory board chairs across all DAX groups.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
More women on executive boards of companies
with government-owned shares, but no increase
in women on supervisory boards

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
As many companies with government-owned shares are
small, they can only be compared to the other groups of
companies examined here to a limited extent.” In addition,
in contrast to the private sector, supervisory board seats in
these companies are often tied to a leading position in public
administration or to political mandates. The share of women
in senior public administration positions and political office
affects the share of women on the supervisory boards of these
companies due to this fact.

As in past years, companies with government-owned shares
had a considerably higher share of women on executive
boards than private sector companies. [n late fall 2023, over
one third (a good 34 percent) of all executive board members
blocks.summarized_text: Government-owned companies have a higher percentage of women on their executive boards compared to private sector companies, largely due to the connection between supervisory board seats and public administration or political mandates. This results in over one third of executive board members being women in these companies as of late fall 2023.

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
at companies with government-owned shares were women,
four percentage points more than in 2022 (Table 4). In addi-
tion, unlike at the large companies in the private sector, the
number of women CEOs has also continued to increase,
recently from nine to 13 women (26 percent).”

In contrast, the share of women on supervisory boards of
companies with government-owned shares declined slightly
and was recently at 39 percent (minus a good one percentage
point). Meanwhile, the share of women supervisory board
chairs has increased to over 36 percent (22 women).
blocks.summarized_text: The percentage of women CEOs at companies with government-owned shares increased from 26 percent to 30 percent in 2023. However, the percentage of women on supervisory boards slightly decreased to 39 percent, with an increase in the number of women holding supervisory board chair positions to over 36 percent.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Banks and insurance companies: Executive
boards catching up while supervisory
boards stagnate

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
The largest companies in the financial sector, the 100 largest
banks and 60 largest insurance companies, have been lagging
significantly behind other large private sector companies for
the past ten years in terms of the share of women on boards.
Recently, however, these two groups began to catch up a bit:
In late fall 2023, the share of women on the executive boards
of the 100 largest banks was nearly 17 percent (an increase
of a good two percentage points) and thus similar to the fig-
ure in the 200 largest private sector companies (excluding
the financial sector) (Table 5). The share of women at the
60 largest insurance companies even increased by almost
three percentage points to over 18 percent. There was also
growth in the share of women CEOs in the financial sector:
The share of women CEOs at banks increased by almost four
percentage points to nearly 12 percent (11 women), while the
share at insurance companies increased by around three per-
centage points to a good eight percent (five women). Thus,
the figures for banks and insurance companies were signif-
icantly higher than the respective figures for the 200 or 100
largest private sector companies.”

Unlike the development on the executive boards, the share of
women on supervisory boards in the financial sector barely
increased; however, as in the other groups of companies, the
increases occurred at a markedly higher level. The share of
women on the supervisory boards of the 100 largest banks
grew by a good half percentage point to around 27 percent.
The share of women on the supervisory boards of the 60
largest insurance companies in the final quarter of 2023
blocks.summarized_text: In late fall 2023, the share of women on the executive boards of the 100 largest banks and 60 largest insurance companies increased significantly, with women making up nearly 17% and over 18% of their respective boards. The share of women CEOs in the financial sector also rose, with women holding nearly 12% of CEO positions in banks and over 8% in insurance companies.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Table 4

Women on executive and supervisory boards of companies with
government-owned shares'

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
was around 29 percent, an increase of one percentage point.
However, compared to 2022 there were fewer women super-
visory board chairs in these two groups: Among the 100 larg-
est banks, there was a decline from 11 women to nine, result-
ing in a share of women of nearly ten percent. Among the
60 largest insurance companies, there was only one woman
supervisory board chair in late fall 2023 (a share of nearly
two percent) compared to four women in 2022."
blocks.summarized_text: In late fall 2023, there was a slight increase in the percentage of women serving as supervisory board chairs in the 100 largest banks and 60 largest insurance companies. However, there were fewer women in these positions compared to 2022, with only nine women in banks and one woman in insurance companies.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Share of women on boards of the largest publicly
listed companies in Germany above EU average

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
A European comparison shows that the share or women on
the supervisory boards of the largest publicly listed compa-
nies in Germany has been above the EU average since the
blocks.summarized_text: Germany consistently surpasses the EU average for the representation of women on the supervisory boards of its largest publicly listed companies. This indicates a relatively higher level of gender diversity in corporate leadership compared to other European countries.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Table 5

Women on the executive and supervisory boards of large banks and insurance companies in Germany'

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
beginning of the 2010s.” In 2023, the EU-wide average for
the share of women on the supervisory boards of the largest
publicly listed companies was nearly 36 percent (Figure 2).
Thus, it was more than two percentage points below the
share for Germany (nearly 38 percent).

However, the share of women on executive boards or among
members with executive functions was considerably lower
than the share of women on supervisory boards across all EU
countries. In Germany, the share was below the EU average
until 2021. [tis only since 2022 that Germany has caught up
and recorded a share of women on executive boards of the
largest publicly listed companies of a good 23 percent in 2023,
thus slightly higher than the EU average of 22 percent. This
blocks.summarized_text: In 2023, the EU-wide average for women on supervisory boards of large publicly listed companies was nearly 36%, slightly lower than Germany's nearly 38%. However, the share of women on executive boards was considerably lower across all EU countries, with Germany only catching up in 2022 with a 23% share in 2023.

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
catching-up process is in part related to the introduction of
the inclusion requirement for women on executive boards.
blocks.summarized_text: The catching-up process is partially driven by the inclusion of women on executive boards. This requirement is aimed at promoting gender equality and is seen as a step towards achieving a more diverse and inclusive leadership.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Legal requirements for appointing women to
supervisory boards and executive boards has
increased share of women

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
In 2015, the Equal Participation of Women and Men in
Leadership Positions in the Private and Public Sectors
Act (Gesetz fiir die gleichberechtigte Teilhabe von Frauen und
Méannern an Fiihrungspositionen in der Privatwirtschaft und
im 6ffentlichen Dienst, FiiPoG I) became law in Germany and
stipulated a statutory gender quota of 30 percent for super-
visory boards. This quota applies to publicly listed companies
that also have employee representation on their supervisory
boards (full co-determination). As of fall 2023, 101 compa-
nies were subject to the quota. Mandatory requirements for
the gender composition of executive boards were not intro-
duced until six years later in 2021 with the Second Equal
Participation of Women and Men in Leadership Positions
in the Public and Private Sectors Act (zweites Gesetz fiir
blocks.summarized_text: In 2015, Germany implemented a gender quota of 30 percent for supervisory boards in publicly listed companies with employee representation. It was followed by a law in 2021 that introduced mandatory requirements for the gender composition of executive boards.

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
die gleichberechtigte Teilhabe von Frauen und Mdnnern an
Fithrungspositionen in der Privatwirtschaft und im éffentlichen
Dienst, FiiPoG LH). This law states, among other things, that
publicly listed companies with full co-determination whose
executive board has at least four members must have at least
one executive board position filled by a member of the under-
represented gender. ”° As of late fall 2023, 63 companies are
required to comply with this regulation. These companies
had, on average, a share of a good 21 percent women on their
executive boards (Table 6). Thus, this group of companies is
behind companies with government-owned shares (34 per-
cent) and just behind the DAX 40 companies (23 percent), but
is ahead of the rest of the groups examined here. The compa-
nies subject to the gender quota for supervisory boards had
an average share of women supervisory board members of
nearly 38 percent, thus putting this group slightly behind the
companies with government-owned shares (a solid 39 per-
cent) and the DAX 40 companies (just over 38 percent), but
ahead of all other groups of companies.

The positive effects of the legal requirements for women on
these boards are becoming visible over time as the shares
of women grow: Within the 200 largest companies, a com-
parison of the companies that are subject to the supervisory
board quota with the companies not subject to it shows that
there has been a signifcantly stronger increase in the share
of women in the “quota companies,” especially from 2014 to
2019 as well as since 2021 (Figure 3). Since 2014, the share
of women on the supervisory boards of the companies sub-
ject to the quota (quota companies) among the 200 largest
companies has increased by over 17 percentage points (from
around 20 to nearly 37 percent). Among the companies in the
top 200 group not subject to the quota, the share of women
on supervisory boards only increased by around 12 perent-
age points (from almost 16 to around 28 percent) in the same
period of time and was, as of late fall 2023, nearly ten per-
centage points lower than the share of women in the quota
companies. There has been barely any growth in the non-
quota companies over the past years, while the quota com-
panies have clearly continued to strive for gender parity even
after reaching the legal minimum of 30 percent.

The inclusion requirement for executive boards introduced
in 2021 is also clearly having an impact: From 2017 to 2020,
the share of women on executive boards of the companies in
the top 200 group that would later be subject to the require-
ment as well as those that would not be subject to the require-
ment developed at the same pace (Figure 4). Since it became
known in 2020 that an inclusion requirement for executive
boards was coming, the companies that would become sub-
ject to the requirement increased the share of women on their
executive boards much more quickly than companies in the
top 200 companies that were not subject to the requirement
blocks.summarized_text: The FiiPoG LH law requires publicly listed companies with full co-determination to have at least one executive board position filled by an under-represented gender. Companies subject to this gender quota for supervisory boards have seen a significant increase in the share of women on their boards, showing positive effects of the legal requirements for women in leadership positions.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Figure 2

Share of women on top boards of the largest publicly listed
companies in Germany and on an EU average
In percent

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Figure 3

Share of women on supervisory boards of the top 200
companies with and without a supervisory board quota
In percent

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Table 6

Women on the executive and supervisory boards of companies subject to the inclusion and quota requirements’

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
in fall 2021.” Of the companies in the top 200 group that are
subject to the inclusion requirement, the share of women on
executive boards was recently 22 percent, which is an over
eight-percentage-point increase since 2020. The rest of the
200 largest companies not subject to the requirement had a
considerably lower share of women on executive boards at
a good 17 percent in fall 2023. Since 2020, it has increased
by around six percentage points, making the gap between
the two groups a little over five percentage points (instead
of under three percentage points in 2020).

Overall, 58 of the 63 companies subject to the inclusion
requirement for the executive board had at least one woman
on the executive board in late fall 2023 (Table 6). The share
of companies in this group that do not have a single woman
on the executive board decreased from 29 percent in 2021
blocks.summarized_text: In Fall 2021, the share of women on executive boards in top 200 companies subject to inclusion requirements was 22%, an increase of over 8 percentage points since 2020. The gap between these companies and the rest of the top 200, with a 17% share, has increased to over 5 percentage points since 2020. In late Fall 2023, 58 out of the 63 companies subject to the requirement had at least one woman on the executive board, showing a decrease from 29% in 2021.

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
to eight percent in the fourth quarter of 2023 (Figure 5).
Nearly 70 percent of these companies recently had exactly
one woman on the executive board. In late fall 2023, just one
fifth of the companies in this group had two or more women
on the executive board.

A comparison of the companies subject to the inclusion
requirement for the executive board with all of the compa-
nies in the top 200 group shows that there are still a consid-
erable number of companies—44 percent as of the fourth
quarter of 2023—in the top 200 group that do not have a
single woman on their executive board. Around 40 percent
had exactly one woman on the executive board, while only
16 percent had two or more women.
blocks.summarized_text: In the fourth quarter of 2023, nearly 70 percent of companies in the top 200 group had only one woman on the executive board, with just one fifth having two or more women. However, a significant portion, 44 percent, of companies in the group still did not have any women on their executive board.

blocks.label: title
blocks.text:
Conclusion: Companies need more committment
to gender parity internally and externally

Bram 9097 +n 39092 tha ehara nf uwnman nn tha avariithva

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
From 2022 to 2023, the share of women on the executive
boards of the largest companies in Germany increased in
all groups of companies analyzed. [In particular, companies
blocks.summarized_text: The share of women on executive boards of the largest companies in Germany saw an increase from 2022 to 2023 in all groups analyzed. This indicates progress towards gender diversity in corporate leadership within the country during this time period.

table_0: Companies subject to the supervisory board quota3

Companies subject to
the executive board
inclusion requirement

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
subject to the 2021 inclusion requirement that had no woman
on the board in 2022 have become active and appointed
women board members. However, in this group of compa-
nies, as in most of the others, the number of women remains
at one. Among the 200 largest companies, for example, there
is still a significant share of executive boards without a single
woman, around 44 percent. Moreover, the position of CEO
remains heavily dominated by men: Only nine women were
he CEO of a top 200 company as of late fall 2023; among
he DAX 40 companies, only one woman had this position.
Not only is the share of women CEOs still negligible, there is
not even an upward trend discernable—rather the opposite.

Much suggests that the introduction of an inclusion require-
ment for executive boards has led to the establishment of a
new social norm. The target of zero women on the executive
board set by many companies a few years ago” has appar-
ently been replaced by a target of one woman on the execu-
ive board. Media coverage and public debate contribute to
he formation of such an implicit quota as a social norm.”
While boards consisting only of men are no longer considered
blocks.summarized_text: Despite the 2021 inclusion requirement, many companies still only have one woman on their board. The position of CEO also remains overwhelmingly male-dominated, with very few women in leadership roles. The introduction of inclusion requirements may have created a new norm of having at least one woman on the executive board.

blocks.label: body
blocks.text:
adequate, there is a danger that the new social norm will legit-
imize boards with a low share of women. Companies may
have little motivation to appoint more women once they have
reached a minimum level of gender diversity, and thereby
keep women underrepresented on executive boards.

To achieve equal participation of women and men on execu-
tive boards, more commitment is required, both within com-
panies and without. When filling executive board positions
via executive search firms, which play an important role as
gatekeepers, supervisory boards can require them to search
specifically for women candidates. Furthermore, supervisory
boards can demand that their executive boards implement
blocks.summarized_text: To ensure gender diversity on executive boards, it is important for companies to continue appointing more women even after reaching a minimum level. Supervisory boards can enforce this by requiring executive search firms to seek out women candidates and demanding implementation of gender diversity initiatives within the company.

data.text: leadership development measures to ensure that enough women are available for executive board positions on companies' internal labor markets. Meanwhile, those observing women's representation on executive boards, such as investors and the public at large, should no longer be satisfied with a bare minimum of gender diversity, but rather demand the actual equal participation of men and women in executive board positions.
